author: Michael Adams
title: Westlake boys track and field coach Mark Hurst dies
text:
Westlake boys track and field coach Mark Hurst dies 10:50 a.m. Sunday, Oct. 4, 2015 | Filed in: High School ﻿ Story Highlights 
Longtime Westlake High School teacher and coach Mark Hurst died Sunday, Oct. 4 at Hospice Austin’s Christopher House. 
He was 59 years old and battled Stage 4 colon, lung and liver cancer for the past 30 months. 
“Mark Hurst has been a beloved coach, friend and mentor at Westlake High School and within our community,” Westlake athletic director Todd Dodge said in a written statement. “His contributions on and off the field are immeasurable, and his impact on generations of student-athletes is incredible. This is a tremendous loss for our Westlake family. We will miss him dearly.” Paul Brick Westlake boys track and field coach Mark Hurst (center) hugs his family during the dedication ceremony of the Mark Hurst Track at the 2014 Chap Relays on Saturday. 
Hurst began teaching at Westlake in 1979, his first job after graduating from Texas Tech University. He taught art at Westlake and served as an assistant coach for the football team. He was also the longtime head coach of Westlake’s boys track and field team. 
Hurst’s track and field teams won 14 district championships. In his 35 years of coaching football, the Chaps have won more than 300 games, including the 1996 state championship game. 
In 2014, the Westlake athletic department named the track at Chaparral Stadium after their longtime coach before the Chap Relays. 
He is survived by his wife, Judy and two children, Hilary and Abby. Judy Hurst is a longtime elementary-school teacher in the Eanes school district.
